abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a highly satisfactory
            project outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts, supported by highly
            satisfactory performances by the Bank and Borrower.
            Regardless of success, lessons point at: 1) issues
            concerning legal and institutional reforms, suggesting a
            flexible stance to legal and institutional reform must be
            clearly reflected in project design. Institutional reform is
            not a one-step intervention; instead, it is an evolutionary
            process in the sense that, as soon as a reform is completed,
            new constraints and new obstacles emerge, and efforts have
            to be taken to resolve these issues. The idea to create a
            new institution with a sole mandate to issue titles, rather
            than using an existing institution, may yield positive
            results; 2) a long-term vision, where continuous
            Government-Bank dialogue may render very positive results in
            the medium and long terms, giving way to a comprehensive
            approach to property rights, to match modern organizations
            and markets. In particular, property rights formalization
            must be complemented by policies that promote access to
            credit, housing, infrastructure, and community empowerment,
            among others. Moreover, institutional reforms are required
            to eliminate high transaction costs in property markets as a
            precondition for an effective demand for formalization.
            Other lessons focus on effective consensus-building, and, on
            special monitoring and evaluation mechanisms.
